an3.102:1.1.pli: “Adhicittamanuyuttena, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā tīṇi nimittāni kālena kālaṃ manasi kātabbāni—
an3.102:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant committed to the higher mind should focus on three bases from time to time:

an3.102:1.2.pli: kālena kālaṃ samādhinimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ, kālena kālaṃ paggahanimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ, kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ.
an3.102:1.2.eng: the basis of immersion, the basis of exertion, and the basis of equanimity.

an3.102:1.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ samādhinimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ kosajjāya saṃvatteyya.
an3.102:1.3.eng: If a mendicant dedicated to the higher mind focuses solely on the basis of immersion, it’s likely their mind will incline to laziness.

an3.102:1.4.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ paggahanimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvatteyya.
an3.102:1.4.eng: If they focus solely on the basis of exertion, it’s likely their mind will incline to restlessness.

an3.102:1.5.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ upekkhānimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ na sammā samādhiyeyya āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an3.102:1.5.eng: If they focus solely on the basis of equanimity, it’s likely their mind won’t properly become immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an3.102:1.6.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ samādhinimittaṃ manasi karoti, kālena kālaṃ paggahanimittaṃ manasi karoti, kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasi karoti, taṃ hoti cittaṃ muduñca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca, na ca pabhaṅgu, sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an3.102:1.6.eng: But when a mendicant dedicated to the higher mind focuses from time to time on the basis of immersion, the basis of exertion, and the basis of equanimity, their mind becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and has become rightly immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an3.102:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā ukkaṃ bandheyya, ukkaṃ bandhitvā ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpeyya, ukkāmukhaṃ ālimpetvā saṇḍāsena jātarūpaṃ gahetvā ukkāmukhe pakkhipeyya, ukkāmukhe pakkhipitvā kālena kālaṃ abhidhamati, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseti, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhati.
an3.102:2.1.eng: It’s like when a goldsmith or a goldsmith’s apprentice prepares a forge, fires the crucible, picks up some native gold with tongs and puts it in the crucible. From time to time they fan it, from time to time they sprinkle water on it, and from time to time they just watch over it.

an3.102:2.2.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ abhidhameyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ ḍaheyya.
an3.102:2.2.eng: If they solely fanned it, the native gold would likely be scorched.

an3.102:2.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ udakena paripphoseyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ nibbāpeyya.
an3.102:2.3.eng: If they solely sprinkled water on it, the native gold would likely cool down.

an3.102:2.4.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ ekantaṃ ajjhupekkheyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ jātarūpaṃ na sammā paripākaṃ gaccheyya.
an3.102:2.4.eng: If they solely watched over it, the native gold would likely not be properly processed.

an3.102:2.5.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā taṃ jātarūpaṃ kālena kālaṃ abhidhamati, kālena kālaṃ udakena paripphoseti, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhati, taṃ hoti jātarūpaṃ muduñca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca, na ca pabhaṅgu, sammā upeti kammāya.
an3.102:2.5.eng: But when that goldsmith fans it from time to time, sprinkles water on it from time to time, and watches over it from time to time, that native gold becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and is ready to be worked.

an3.102:2.6.pli: Yassā yassā ca pilandhanavikatiyā ākaṅkhati—yadi paṭṭikāya, yadi kuṇḍalāya, yadi gīveyyake, yadi suvaṇṇamālāya—tañcassa atthaṃ anubhoti.
an3.102:2.6.eng: Then the goldsmith can successfully create any kind of ornament they want, whether a bracelet, earrings, a necklace, or a golden garland.

an3.102:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyuttena bhikkhunā tīṇi nimittāni kālena kālaṃ manasi kātabbāni—
an3.102:3.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant committed to the higher mind should focus on three bases from time to time:

an3.102:3.2.pli: kālena kālaṃ samādhinimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ, kālena kālaṃ paggahanimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ, kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasi kātabbaṃ.
an3.102:3.2.eng: the basis of immersion, the basis of exertion, and the basis of equanimity. …

an3.102:3.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ samādhinimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ kosajjāya saṃvatteyya.

an3.102:3.4.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ paggahanimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ uddhaccāya saṃvatteyya.

an3.102:3.5.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu ekantaṃ upekkhānimittaṃyeva manasi kareyya, ṭhānaṃ taṃ cittaṃ na sammā samādhiyeyya āsavānaṃ khayāya.

an3.102:3.6.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, adhicittamanuyutto bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ samādhinimittaṃ manasi karoti, kālena kālaṃ paggahanimittaṃ manasi karoti, kālena kālaṃ upekkhānimittaṃ manasi karoti, taṃ hoti cittaṃ muduñca kammaniyañca pabhassarañca, na ca pabhaṅgu, sammā samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an3.102:3.6.eng: When a mendicant dedicated to the higher mind focuses from time to time on the basis of immersion, the basis of exertion, and the basis of equanimity, their mind becomes pliable, workable, and radiant, not brittle, and has become rightly immersed in samādhi for the ending of defilements.

an3.102:3.7.pli: Yassa yassa ca abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassa dhammassa cittaṃ abhininnāmeti abhiññāsacchikiriyāya, tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane.
an3.102:3.7.eng: They extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.

an3.102:4.1.eng: If they wish: ‘May I wield the many kinds of psychic power’ …

an3.102:4.2.eng: ‘With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, may I hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.’ …

an3.102:4.3.eng: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives.’ …

an3.102:4.4.eng: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn.’ …

an3.102:4.5.eng: ‘May I realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.102:4.6.pli: tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane”ti.
an3.102:4.6.eng: They are capable of realizing these things, since each and every one is within range.”

an3.103:1.1.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
an3.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

an3.103:1.2.pli: ‘ko nu kho loke assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?
an3.103:1.2.eng: ‘What’s the gratification in the world? What’s the drawback? What’s the escape?’

an3.103:1.4.pli: ‘yaṃ kho lokaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ loke assādo.
an3.103:1.4.eng: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from the world: this is its gratification.

an3.103:1.5.pli: Yaṃ loko anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo, ayaṃ loke ādīnavo.
an3.103:1.5.eng: That the world is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

an3.103:1.6.pli: Yo loke chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ loke nissaraṇan’ti.
an3.103:1.6.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for the world: this is its escape.’

an3.103:1.7.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, evaṃ lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an3.103:1.7.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an3.103:1.8.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, evaṃ lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an3.103:1.8.eng: But when I did truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an3.103:1.9.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

an3.103:1.10.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
an3.103:1.10.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

an3.104:1.1.pli: “Lokassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, assādapariyesanaṃ acariṃ. Yo loke assādo tadajjhagamaṃ.
an3.104:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I went in search of the world’s gratification, and I found it.

an3.104:1.2.pli: Yāvatako loke assādo, paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
an3.104:1.2.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of gratification in the world.

an3.104:1.3.pli: Lokassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ādīnavapariyesanaṃ acariṃ. Yo loke ādīnavo tadajjhagamaṃ.
an3.104:1.3.eng: I went in search of the world’s drawbacks, and I found them.

an3.104:1.4.pli: Yāvatako loke ādīnavo, paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
an3.104:1.4.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of the drawbacks in the world.

an3.104:1.5.pli: Lokassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nissaraṇapariyesanaṃ acariṃ. Yaṃ loke nissaraṇaṃ tadajjhagamaṃ.
an3.104:1.5.eng: I went in search of escape from the world, and I found it.

an3.104:1.6.pli: Yāvatakaṃ loke nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
an3.104:1.6.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of escape from the world.

an3.104:1.7.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an3.104:1.7.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an3.104:1.8.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an3.104:1.8.eng: But when I did truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an3.104:1.9.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

an3.104:1.10.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
an3.104:1.10.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

an3.105:1.1.pli: “No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, loke assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā loke sārajjeyyuṃ.
an3.105:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in the world, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

an3.105:1.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi loke assādo, tasmā sattā loke sārajjanti.
an3.105:1.2.eng: But because there is gratification in the world, sentient beings are aroused by it.

an3.105:1.3.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, loke ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā loke nibbindeyyuṃ.
an3.105:1.3.eng: If the world had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

an3.105:1.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi loke ādīnavo, tasmā sattā loke nibbindanti.
an3.105:1.4.eng: But since the world has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

an3.105:1.5.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, loke nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā lokamhā nissareyyuṃ.
an3.105:1.5.eng: If there were no escape from the world, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

an3.105:1.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi loke nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā lokamhā nissaranti.
an3.105:1.6.eng: But since there is an escape from the world, sentient beings do escape from it.

an3.105:1.7.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, sattā lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsuṃ, neva tāva, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā vihariṃsu.
an3.105:1.7.eng: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.

an3.105:1.8.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, sattā lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsuṃ, atha, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharantī”ti.
an3.105:1.8.eng: But when sentient beings truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.”

an3.106:1.1.pli: “Ye keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti,
an3.106:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are.

an3.106:1.2.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
an3.106:1.2.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

an3.106:1.3.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā lokassa assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti,
an3.106:1.3.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand the world’s gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are.

an3.106:1.4.pli: te kho, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
an3.106:1.4.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

an3.107:1.1.eng: “Singing is regarded as wailing in the training of the Noble One.

an3.107:1.2.pli: Ummattakamidaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye yadidaṃ naccaṃ.

an3.107:1.3.pli: Komārakamidaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye yadidaṃ ativelaṃ dantavidaṃsakahasitaṃ.
an3.107:1.3.eng: Too much laughter, showing the teeth, is regarded as childish.

an3.107:1.4.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, setughāto gīte, setughāto nacce, alaṃ vo dhammappamoditānaṃ sataṃ sitaṃ sitamattāyā”ti.
an3.107:1.4.eng: So break off singing and dancing; and when you’re appropriately pleased, it’s enough to simply smile.”

an3.108:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are three indulgences that never satisfy.

an3.108:1.6.pli: Imesaṃ, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ paṭisevanāya natthi tittī”ti.
an3.108:1.6.eng: These are the three indulgences that never satisfy.”

an3.109:1.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.109:1.1.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an3.109:1.2.pli: “citte, gahapati, arakkhite kāyakammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti, manokammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti.
an3.109:1.2.eng: “Householder, when the mind is unprotected, deeds of body, speech, and mind are unprotected.

an3.109:1.3.pli: Tassa arakkhitakāyakammantassa arakkhitavacīkammantassa arakkhitamanokammantassa kāyakammampi avassutaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi avassutaṃ hoti, manokammampi avassutaṃ hoti.
an3.109:1.3.eng: When deeds are unprotected, they fester.

an3.109:1.4.pli: Tassa avassutakāyakammantassa avassutavacīkammantassa avassutamanokammantassa kāyakammampi pūtikaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi pūtikaṃ hoti, manokammampi pūtikaṃ hoti.
an3.109:1.4.eng: When deeds fester, they become rotten.

an3.109:1.5.pli: Tassa pūtikāyakammantassa pūtivacīkammantassa pūtimanokammantassa na bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.109:1.5.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are rotten will not have a good death.

an3.109:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, kūṭāgāre ducchanne kūṭampi arakkhitaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi arakkhitā honti, bhittipi arakkhitā hoti;
an3.109:2.1.eng: It’s like a bungalow with a bad roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are unprotected.

an3.109:2.2.pli: kūṭampi avassutaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi avassutā honti, bhittipi avassutā hoti;

an3.109:2.3.pli: kūṭampi pūtikaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi pūtikā honti, bhittipi pūtikā hoti.

an3.109:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, gahapati, citte arakkhite kāyakammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti, manokammampi arakkhitaṃ hoti.
an3.109:3.1.eng: In the same way, when the mind is unprotected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are unprotected. …

an3.109:3.2.pli: Tassa arakkhitakāyakammantassa arakkhitavacīkammantassa arakkhitamanokammantassa kāyakammampi avassutaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi avassutaṃ hoti, manokammampi avassutaṃ hoti.

an3.109:3.3.pli: Tassa avassutakāyakammantassa avassutavacīkammantassa avassutamanokammantassa kāyakammampi pūtikaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi pūtikaṃ hoti, manokammampi pūtikaṃ hoti.

an3.109:3.4.pli: Tassa pūtikāyakammantassa pūtivacīkammantassa pūtimanokammantassa na bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.109:3.4.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are rotten will not have a good death.

an3.109:4.1.pli: Citte, gahapati, rakkhite kāyakammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti, manokammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti.
an3.109:4.1.eng: When the mind is protected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are protected.

an3.109:4.2.pli: Tassa rakkhitakāyakammantassa rakkhitavacīkammantassa rakkhitamanokammantassa kāyakammampi anavassutaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi anavassutaṃ hoti, manokammampi anavassutaṃ hoti.
an3.109:4.2.eng: When deeds are protected, they don’t fester.

an3.109:4.3.pli: Tassa anavassutakāyakammantassa anavassutavacīkammantassa anavassutamanokammantassa kāyakammampi apūtikaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi apūtikaṃ hoti, manokammampi apūtikaṃ hoti.
an3.109:4.3.eng: When deeds don’t fester, they don’t become rotten.

an3.109:4.4.pli: Tassa apūtikāyakammantassa apūtivacīkammantassa apūtimanokammantassa bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.109:4.4.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind aren’t rotten will have a good death.

an3.109:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, kūṭāgāre succhanne kūṭampi rakkhitaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi rakkhitā honti, bhittipi rakkhitā hoti;
an3.109:5.1.eng: It’s like a bungalow with a good roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are protected.

an3.109:5.2.pli: kūṭampi anavassutaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi anavassutā honti, bhittipi anavassutā hoti;

an3.109:5.3.pli: kūṭampi apūtikaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi apūtikā honti, bhittipi apūtikā hoti.

an3.109:6.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, gahapati, citte rakkhite kāyakammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti, manokammampi rakkhitaṃ hoti.
an3.109:6.1.eng: In the same way, when the mind is protected, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are protected. …

an3.109:6.2.pli: Tassa rakkhitakāyakammantassa rakkhitavacīkammantassa rakkhitamanokammantassa kāyakammampi anavassutaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi anavassutaṃ hoti, manokammampi anavassutaṃ hoti.

an3.109:6.3.pli: Tassa anavassutakāyakammantassa anavassutavacīkammantassa anavassutamanokammantassa kāyakammampi apūtikaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi apūtikaṃ hoti, manokammampi apūtikaṃ hoti.

an3.109:6.4.pli: Tassa apūtikāyakammantassa apūtivacīkammantassa apūtimanokammantassa bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā”ti.
an3.109:6.4.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind aren’t rotten will have a good death.”

an3.11:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ñāto bhikkhu bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanadukkhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an3.11:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a well-known mendicant who has three qualities is acting for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.

an3.11:1.3.pli: Ananulomike kāyakamme samādapeti, ananulomike vacīkamme samādapeti, ananulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti.
an3.11:1.3.eng: They encourage deeds of body and speech, as well as principles, that don’t reinforce good qualities.

an3.11:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato ñāto bhikkhu bahujanaahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanadukkhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an3.11:1.4.eng: A well-known mendicant who possesses these three qualities is acting for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.

an3.11:2.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato ñāto bhikkhu bahujanahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanasukhāya, bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an3.11:2.1.eng: A well-known mendicant who has three qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an3.11:2.3.pli: Anulomike kāyakamme samādapeti, anulomike vacīkamme samādapeti, anulomikesu dhammesu samādapeti.
an3.11:2.3.eng: They encourage deeds of body and speech, as well as principles, that reinforce good qualities.

an3.11:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato ñāto bhikkhu bahujanahitāya paṭipanno hoti bahujanasukhāya, bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
an3.11:2.4.eng: A well-known mendicant who possesses these three qualities is acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

an3.110:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.110:1.1.eng: Seated to one side, the Buddha said to the householder Anāthapiṇḍika:

an3.110:1.2.pli: “citte, gahapati, byāpanne kāyakammampi byāpannaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi byāpannaṃ hoti, manokammampi byāpannaṃ hoti.
an3.110:1.2.eng: “Householder, when the mind is fallen, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are fallen.

an3.110:1.3.pli: Tassa byāpannakāyakammantassa byāpannavacīkammantassa byāpannamanokammantassa na bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.110:1.3.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are fallen will not have a good death.

an3.110:1.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, kūṭāgāre ducchanne kūṭampi byāpannaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi byāpannā honti, bhittipi byāpannā hoti;
an3.110:1.4.eng: It’s like a bungalow with a bad roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls fall in.

an3.110:1.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho, gahapati, citte byāpanne kāyakammampi byāpannaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi byāpannaṃ hoti, manokammampi byāpannaṃ hoti.
an3.110:1.5.eng: In the same way, when the mind is fallen, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are fallen.

an3.110:1.6.pli: Tassa byāpannakāyakammantassa byāpannavacīkammantassa byāpannamanokammantassa na bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, na bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.110:1.6.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are fallen will not have a good death.

an3.110:2.1.pli: Citte, gahapati, abyāpanne kāyakammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti, manokammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti.
an3.110:2.1.eng: When the mind is not fallen, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are not fallen.

an3.110:2.2.pli: Tassa abyāpannakāyakammantassa abyāpannavacīkammantassa abyāpannamanokammantassa bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā.
an3.110:2.2.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are not fallen will have a good death.

an3.110:2.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, kūṭāgāre succhanne kūṭampi abyāpannaṃ hoti, gopānasiyopi abyāpannā honti, bhittipi abyāpannā hoti;
an3.110:2.3.eng: It’s like a bungalow with a good roof. The roof peak, rafters, and walls are not fallen in.

an3.110:2.4.pli: evamevaṃ kho, gahapati, citte abyāpanne kāyakammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti, vacīkammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti, manokammampi abyāpannaṃ hoti.
an3.110:2.4.eng: In the same way, when the mind is not fallen, bodily, verbal, and mental deeds are not fallen.

an3.110:2.5.pli: Tassa abyāpannakāyakammantassa …pe… abyāpannamanokammantassa bhaddakaṃ maraṇaṃ hoti, bhaddikā kālakiriyā”ti.
an3.110:2.5.eng: Someone whose deeds of body, speech, and mind are not fallen will have a good death.”

an3.111:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.111:1.3.pli: Lobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, doso nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, moho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.111:1.3.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.111:1.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, lobhapakataṃ kammaṃ lobhajaṃ lobhanidānaṃ lobhasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ akusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sāvajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati.
an3.111:1.4.eng: Any deed that emerges from greed, hate, or delusion—born, sourced, and originated from greed, hate, or delusion—is unskillful, blameworthy, results in suffering, and leads to the creation of more deeds, not their cessation.

an3.111:1.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, dosapakataṃ kammaṃ dosajaṃ dosanidānaṃ dosasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ akusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sāvajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati.

an3.111:1.6.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, mohapakataṃ kammaṃ mohajaṃ mohanidānaṃ mohasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ akusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sāvajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati.

an3.111:1.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.111:1.7.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.111:2.1.eng: There are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.111:2.3.pli: Alobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, adoso nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya, amoho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.111:2.3.eng: Contentment, love, and understanding are sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.111:2.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, alobhapakataṃ kammaṃ alobhajaṃ alobhanidānaṃ alobhasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ anavajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sukhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati.
an3.111:2.4.eng: Any deed that emerges from contentment, love, or understanding—born, sourced, and originated from contentment, love, or understanding—is skillful, blameless, results in happiness, and leads to the cessation of more deeds, not their creation.

an3.111:2.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, adosapakataṃ kammaṃ adosajaṃ adosanidānaṃ adosasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ anavajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sukhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati.

an3.111:2.6.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, amohapakataṃ kammaṃ amohajaṃ amohanidānaṃ amohasamudayaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kusalaṃ taṃ kammaṃ anavajjaṃ taṃ kammaṃ sukhavipākaṃ, taṃ kammaṃ kammanirodhāya saṃvattati, na taṃ kammaṃ kammasamudayāya saṃvattati.

an3.111:2.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāyā”ti.
an3.111:2.7.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.”

an3.112:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.112:1.3.pli: Atīte, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati;
an3.112:1.3.eng: Desire comes up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:1.4.pli: anāgate, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati;

an3.112:1.5.pli: paccuppanne, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati.

an3.112:1.6.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, atīte chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati?
an3.112:1.6.eng: And how does desire come up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present?

an3.112:1.7.pli: Atīte, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti.
an3.112:1.7.eng: In your heart you think about and consider things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:1.8.pli: Tassa atīte chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato chando jāyati.
an3.112:1.8.eng: When you do this, desire comes up,

an3.112:1.9.eng: and you get attached to those things.

an3.112:1.10.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, saṃyojanaṃ vadāmi yo cetaso sārāgo.
an3.112:1.10.eng: This lust in the heart is what I call a fetter.

an3.112:1.11.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, atīte chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati.
an3.112:1.11.eng: That’s how desire comes up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, anāgate chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati?

an3.112:2.2.pli: Anāgate, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti.

an3.112:2.3.pli: Tassa anāgate chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato chando jāyati.

an3.112:2.5.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, saṃyojanaṃ vadāmi yo cetaso sārāgo.

an3.112:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, anāgate chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati.

an3.112:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, paccuppanne chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati?

an3.112:3.2.pli: Paccuppanne, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti.

an3.112:3.3.pli: Tassa paccuppanne chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha cetasā anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato chando jāyati.

an3.112:3.5.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, saṃyojanaṃ vadāmi yo cetaso sārāgo.

an3.112:3.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paccuppanne chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando jāyati.

an3.112:3.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāya.
an3.112:3.7.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.112:4.1.eng: There are these three sources that give rise to deeds.

an3.112:4.3.pli: Atīte, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati;
an3.112:4.3.eng: Desire doesn’t come up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:4.4.pli: anāgate, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati;

an3.112:4.5.pli: paccuppanne, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati.

an3.112:5.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, atīte chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati?
an3.112:5.1.eng: And how does desire not come up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present?

an3.112:5.2.pli: Atītānaṃ, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniyānaṃ dhammānaṃ āyatiṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti.
an3.112:5.2.eng: You understand the future result of things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:5.3.eng: When you know this, you grow disillusioned,

an3.112:5.4.pli: Tadabhinivattetvā cetasā abhinivijjhitvā paññāya ativijjha passati.
an3.112:5.4.eng: your heart becomes dispassionate, and you see it with penetrating wisdom.

an3.112:5.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, atīte chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati.
an3.112:5.5.eng: That’s how desire doesn’t come up for things that stimulate desire and greed in the past, future, or present.

an3.112:6.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, anāgate chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati?

an3.112:6.2.pli: Anāgatānaṃ, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniyānaṃ dhammānaṃ āyatiṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti.

an3.112:6.4.pli: Tadabhinivattetvā cetasā abhinivijjhitvā paññāya ativijjha passati.

an3.112:6.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, anāgate chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati.

an3.112:7.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, paccuppanne chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati?

an3.112:7.2.pli: Paccuppannānaṃ, bhikkhave, chandarāgaṭṭhāniyānaṃ dhammānaṃ āyatiṃ vipākaṃ pajānāti, āyatiṃ vipākaṃ viditvā tadabhinivatteti, tadabhinivattetvā cetasā abhinivijjhitvā paññāya ativijjha passati.

an3.112:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paccuppanne chandarāgaṭṭhāniye dhamme ārabbha chando na jāyati.

an3.112:7.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi nidānāni kammānaṃ samudayāyā”ti.
an3.112:7.4.eng: These are three sources that give rise to deeds.”

an3.113:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three are bound for a place of loss, bound for hell, if they don’t give up this fault.

an3.113:1.3.eng: Someone who is unchaste, but claims to be chaste;

an3.113:1.4.pli: yo ca suddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carantaṃ amūlakena abrahmacariyena anuddhaṃseti,
an3.113:1.4.eng: someone who makes a groundless accusation of unchastity against a person whose chastity is pure;

an3.113:1.5.pli: yo cāyaṃ evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi: ‘natthi kāmesu doso’ti, so tāya kāmesu pātabyataṃ āpajjati.
an3.113:1.5.eng: and someone who has the view, ‘There is nothing wrong with sensual pleasures,’ so they throw themselves into sensual pleasures.

an3.113:1.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo āpāyikā nerayikā idamappahāyā”ti.
an3.113:1.6.eng: These are the three who are bound for a place of loss, bound for hell, if they don’t give up this fault.”
